abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.para: This document serves two purposes; first it is a brief summary of the services I maintained at Lund University Libraries (LUB). It also gives an overview of the documentation I produced when leaving, and it kind of table of content for those documents.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The reason I write this package of documents is that I'm quitting. It is meant to be a self-contained package of documents to be consulted by colleagues who run or use stuff I built while working within Lund University Libraries.
This is the material that can be distributed freely. There are parts of this documentation that are sensitive and kept on secure areas of the server.

sect2.title: Conventions
sect2.para: It is a substantial amount of texts, and they are split into several parts. This document is meant to serve as a global table of contents for lot.
Links to external information sources are given as end notes, whereas links and cross references are given as hypertext links within the text.

sect1.title: Services
sect1.para: I used to maintain quite a few services. This is a complete list of stuff that might be of interest for BD to maintain in spite of the fact that I'm no longer here at Lund University.

sect2.title: Portals
sect2.para: By portals I understand a web site in general, used for publishing of articles, links etc in a focused area for defined target audience.
These services are currently running on balder.lub.lu.se, as a part of the Keystone DLS Hotel I have installed there.

sect2.title: Electronic publishing
sect2.para: By electronic publishing I understand services that are meant to disseminate digital content and metadata about that content.

The two services are are closely tied together, and are documented as one integrated system. These services are currently running on balder.lub.lu.se, as a part of the Keystone DLS Hotel I have installed there. The Xerxes and Scripta services required some modifications in order to be possible to run from a single set of software. The modifications are documented in a separate document.

Still, the two e-publishing services are different in many ways. They have different history, and inherits data from earlier services and the maintenance of older data is different. For Scripta there is still a need to maintain data from the old dissdb.

Masters theses are produced en mass, and for some departments it the sheer volume makes it worthwhile to have a local service. Thus harvested data constituted a substantial input to Xerxes. To that end there is a special Xerxes Bot.
A few departments take advantage of the list courses facility

sect2.title: Digitization
sect2.para: By digitization I understand services meant to make content that has previously been available in digital form accessible to a wider audience.
Laurentius is currently running on hex.lub.lu.se.

sect2.title: Cataloging
sect2.para: A cataloging service is a service which is meant for cataloging, or for making a catalogue available in digital form. The three services listed below are very different, but still they share important characteristics.
As noted above, Xerxes and Scripta share important characteristics. As far as cataloging is concerned they share metadata system. Since they share metadata definition they also share cataloging tool.
I have also recieved a document containing a mixture of problems and to-do-list items. I provide answers to these questions here
